questions.text: A patient is having fatigue and weakness. On examination, his Hb was low, iron levels were also low. Patient noted that his wound healing is delayed since last 1 year. Which vitamin deficiency is possible in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient is suffering from Scurvy which occur due to deficiency of vitamin C.
  • Vitamin C is required for absorption of iron in intestine as it is a cofactor for conversion of ferric ion (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) form which is absorbable form of iron. In Vit C def this is impaired leading to low iron and consequently low Hb.
  • Other manifestations of advanced scurvy include numerous small hemorrhages caused by fragile blood vessels, tooth loss, poor wound healing and the reopening of old wounds, bone pain and degeneration.
  • Infantile Scurvy is known as Barlow’s disease.

questions.text: A patient from Jaipur has fluorosis and typical brown staining of teeth. Which bony change will occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Fluorosis is caused by high fluoride contamination of drinking water and food material due to presence of industrial pollutants.

It is of two type:

  1. Dental Fluorosis
  2. Skeletal Fluorosis
  • Dental fluorosis generally occur in children below 8 years of age.
  • High systemic fluoride exposures can lead to skeletal fluorosis, a condition hallmarked by osteosclerosis

Osteosclerosis

  • Abnormal hardening of bone
  • Elevation in bone density

questions.text: Eye–hand coordination lies at the core of our daily actions and interactions with objects and people around us and is central to understanding how the brain creates internal models of the action space and generates movement within it. The structure that integrates impulses for eye-hand coordination is.
questions.solution:
Circuit for eye-hand coordination

  • Visual pathway sends one set of impulses to superior colliculus; these visual impulses are then carried into cerebellum by tectocerebellar tract.
  • Cerebellum and the tectospinal tract(from superior colliculus to spinal cord) will accordingly coordinate the hand movements.
  • Area 17has the primary visual area(V1 – visual cortex; occipital lobe).
  • Pretectal nucleus is the interneuron involved in the pupillary light reflex.
  • II N is the sensory nerve, from where impulse is passed on to Edinger-Westphal nucleus (III N – the motor nerve for light reflex) via pretectal nucleus.

Frontal eye fields(area 8; frontal lobe) control the voluntary tracking an objectin the field of vision

questions.text: A patient with intellectual disability was found to have hyperuricemia. Self-mutilation behavior was also noticed. Which of the following enzyme is deficient?
questions.solution:
• The child is exhibiting the symptoms of Lesch–Nyhan syndrome, which is a deficiency of HGPRT (hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase) activity.
  • HGPRT will convert the free bases hypoxanthine, or guanine, plus PRPP (5′-phosphoribosyl 1′-pyrophosphate) to the nucleotides IMP, or GMP, plus pyrophosphate in Salvage pathway.

  • Complete deficiency of HGPRT leads to Lesch Nyhan syndrome with clinical features of increased uric acid levels and self-mutilation behavior due to neurotoxic nature of increased PRPP.
  • Partial deficiency of HGPRT causes Kelly Seegmiller syndrome with only increased uric acid levels but no self-mutilation behavior.

  • Substantia nigra is developed from mesencephalon therefore 1st statement is wrong.
  • Lesion in this area causes Parkinson’s disease and not Alzheimer’s disease. Therefore, 2nd statement is also wrong.

questions.text: Serum prolactin is generally measured by RIA or IRMA. The upper limit of the normal range is generally reported to be 15 to 20 ng/mL in men and 20 to 25 ng/mL in women. Because of diurnal changes and transient increases after meals, routine samples are mostly taken at mid-morning. Highest levels of serum prolactin are secreted during which phase?

choices.text: Corresponds to increased levels of estrogen

questions.solution:
• Normally The upper limit of the normal range is generally reported to be 15 to 20 ng/mL in men and 20 to 25ng/mL in women,
  • PRL secretion is pulsatile, with the highest secretory peaks occurring during rapid eye movement sleep.
  • Peak serum PRL levels (up to 30 g/L) occur between 4:00 and 6:00 a.m. The circulating half-life of PRL is about 50 min.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding Bainbridge reflex?

choices.text: Caused by increase in atrial pressure
Causes damming of blood in pulmonary circulation

questions.solution:
Bainbridge reflex:

  • Increase in atrial pressure causes increase in heart rate by nervous reflex called Bainbridge reflex.
  • 40 – 60 % increase in rate is due to this reflex while 15% increase is by direct effect of increased atrial volume to stretch sinus node.
  • Stretch receptors of atria that elicit Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through vagus nerve to medulla of brain.
  • These efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal & sympathetic nerves to increase H.R & strength of heart contraction.
  • This reflex helps prevent damming of blood in atria, veins & pulmonary circulation
  • Best known nerve mechanisms for arterial pressure control
  • Reflex is initiated by stretch receptors called baroreceptors /press receptors located at specific points in walls of several large systemic arteries
  • A rise in arterial pressure stretches baroreceptor & causes them to transmit signals into CNS.
  • “feedback” signals are then sent back through autonomic nervous system to circulation to reduce arterial pressure downward towards the normal level

questions.text: Charcot Marie Tooth Disease is a peripheral neuropathy which leads to progressive muscle weakness typically noticeable in adolescence or early adulthood. In this disease longer nerves are affected first, symptoms usually begin in the feet and lower legs and then can affect the fingers, hands, and arms. Which among the following defective connexin causes the disease?
questions.solution:
• Charcot Marie Tooth disease is a peripheral neuropathy.
  • It results from defective connexin-32 that forms gap junctions between adjacent Schwann cells.
  • Defect in connexin 40 – Idiopathic atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency after an accident. On examination his left foot is hanging, and he is not able to extend his toe and do inversion but eversion is normal. There is also loss of sensations between 1st and 2nd toe. Which of the following nerves has been injured?
questions.solution:
• Deep fibular (peroneal) nerve is responsible for innervating the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg, which are responsible for toe extension, foot dorsiflexion, and inversion.Injury to this nerve will result in foot drop and loss of sensation between the first and second toes.
  • Injury to the tibial nerve affects the posterior compartment muscles of the leg, which are responsible for plantar flexion and toe flexion, as well as the intrinsic muscles of the sole of the foot.
  • The superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve innervates the fibularis longus and brevis muscles, which provide eversion of the foot.
  • If the common fibular (peroneal) nerve were injured, eversion of the foot and plantar flexion would be lost in addition to dorsiflexion and inversion.

questions.text: In which if the following disorder, ATP 7A protein is deficient?
questions.solution:
Menke’e Disease Wilson’s disease
  • Cu Deficiency
  • Cu Excess
  • ATP-7A protein defective
  • ATP-7B protein defective
  • X-linked recessive
  • Autosomal recessive
  • ATP-7A is present in intestine for absorption of Cu. Its deficiency causes:
    • ↓ Cu (Cu stays in intestinal cell, unable to enter blood)
    • ↓ ceruloplasmin (cp) (due to insufficient Cu to form cp)
  • ATP-7B is present in liver to throw Cu in bile and also incorporates Cu incp. Its deficiency causes:
    • ↑ Cu in liver (due to non-excretion from body)
    • ↓ ceruloplasmin (cp) (due to non-incorporation of Cu in cp)

Note: ↓ ceruloplasmin (cp) is common between Menke and Wilson Disease

Menke’s kinky hair syndrome- Clinical features

  • premature birth
  • hypotonia
  • growth retardation
  • mental retardation
  • grey depigmented hair:
    • tyrosinase (an oxidase) is affected as oxidases require Cu
    • tyrosinase is required for synthesis of Melanin.
    • so, melanin synthesis is decreased causing grey hair
  • brittle kinky hair
    • As lysyl oxidase affected, so defective and weak collagen synthesis
  • Decreased Cu in blood and urine

questions.text: In an accident, a car’s front and rear wheels went over the left hand of woman. On examination multiple lacerations are present over forearm of left hand and she is unable to flex the distal interphalangeal joints of the fourth and fifth digits. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
• Loss of flexion at Distal Inter Phalangeal joint occurs due to loss of function of FDP (Flexor Digitorum Profundus).
  • Flexor digitorum profundus is dually innervated by the ulnar nerve to the medial phalanges (Finger 4 & 5) and the median nerve for the lateral phalanges (Finger 2 & 3).
  • Because of the superficial course of the ulnar nerve, it is vulnerable to injury by laceration. Such an injury would result in an inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joints of the 4th and 5th digits.
  • The lumbricals function to flex the MCP (Metacarpophalangeal) joints and assist in extending the IP joints.
  • The interossei adduct and abduct the fingers(along with MCP flexion).

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented in emergency in unconscious condition. An MRI showed degeneration of the cerebellar vermis. Which of the following cells is most notably destroyed in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Alcohol is directly toxic to the cerebellum and mainly causes degeneration of the anterosuperior vermis due to the shrinkage or atrophy of the Purkinje cells.
  • Chronic alcoholism leads to a significant loss of Purkinje cells. In addition, there is also associated vitamin B1 deficiency.
  • The Golgi cell exerts an inhibitory influence on the synapse between the mossy fibres and the granule cell within the cerebellar glomerulus.
  • Basket cells have a direct inhibitory effect on Purkinje cells. In the cerebellar glomerulus, the afferent mossy fibres form a synapse with the granule cell.

questions.text: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common type of muscular dystrophy. Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding Duchene Muscular Dystrophy?

choices.text: It is an X- linked recessive disorder
Skeletal muscle wasting occurs due to abnormalities of the contractile filaments
Deficiency of the protein dystrophin (427-kDa) in skeletal muscle
Death may occur from respiratory failure

questions.solution:
• Duchenne’s muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder. There is a genetic defect in the dystrophin gene; it results in the deficiency of the protein dystrophin (427-kDa) in skeletal muscle
  • Dystrophin is a large protein that is present on the intracellular surface of the sarcolemma, it makes dystrophin-glycoprotein complex.
  • In DMD, there is severe muscle wasting; death may occur from respiratory failure.
  • Dystrophin is absent in muscle; Skeletal muscle wasting occurs due to abnormalities of the contractile filament, it's not an abnormality, protein itself is absent.
  • A milder form -Becker muscular dystrophy, here dystrophin is present but altered or reduced in amount.

questions.text: All the following statements are false regarding anterior axillary lymph nodes EXCEPT-

Drains the lateral aspect of mammary gland

questions.solution:
• Anterior axillary / pectoral lymph nodes are present along the lateral thoracic vein on the anterior wall of axilla on pectoral muscle.
  • These drains the lateral aspect of mammary gland and finally drains into central axillary lymph nodes.
  • Apical group of lymph nodes are the terminal axillary lymph nodes.

questions.text: Cell attachment is the initial step in a cascade of cell–biomaterial interactions and is important to cellular processes such as cell guidance, proliferation, and differentiation. Which of the following junctions permits the passage of ions, solute and signal molecules in between the adjacent cells?
questions.solution:
• Hemidesmosomes are specialized junctional complexes, that contribute to the attachment of epithelial cells to the underlying basement membrane.
  • Macula adherens or desmosomes provide mechanical adhesion by linking the cytoskelet on of adjacent cells together.
  • Zonula adherens or adhering junctions cause the epithelial cells to be organized into a properly polarized epithelium.
  • Zonula occludens or tight junctionspermit the passage of ions, solute and intracellular signalling molecules in between adjacent cells.

questions.text: Sibson’s fascia is a degenerated tendon of scalenus minimus covering the thoracic inlet. Which of the following is incorrect statement regarding sibson’s fascia?

choices.text: Attached to inner border of first rib medially
Attached to transverse process of C7 laterally
Separates subclavian artery from subclavian vein

questions.solution:
• Sibson’s fascia is a modification of the endothoracic fascia in the supraclavicular region, covering the thoracic inlet.
  • It is a degenerated tendon of the scalenus minimus.
  • Attachment: Transverse process of the C7 vertebra and inner border of 1st rib.
  • It separates the subclavian artery and vein (running on the posterosuperior surface of the first rib) from the cervical pleura.

questions.text: Molecular mimicry is defined as the theoretical possibility that sequence similarities between foreign and self-peptides are sufficient to result in the cross-activation of auto reactive T or B cells by pathogen-derived peptides. Which of the following endocrine disorder is a result of molecular mimicry?
questions.solution:
Hashimotothyroiditis is caused by an abnormal immune response that includes the production of antithyroid antibodies against the thyroid follicular cells, microsomes, and TSH receptors.

Molecular Mimicry

  • A new theory explains how an immune system can be “tricked” into attacking the thyroid cells.
  • Yersinia resides in intestinal bacteria has been found to share identical amino acid sequences when compared to the TSH receptor, thyroglobulin,thyroperoxidase [TPO], and Sodium Iodide symporter [NIS].
  • This explains the increased antibodies found on lab panels in Hashimoto's patients.
  • These are the antibodies to thyroglobulin and thyroperoxidase (TPO) commonly used by the doctor to confirm a diagnosis of Hashimotos Thyroiditis.

TSH Receptor Antibodies

Comes in 2 varieties.

  1. The first type, the TSH receptor is stimulated →Grave’ Disease and hyperthyroidism.
  2. The second variety, the TSH receptor is blocked→Hashimoto’s disease.
  • Although both Graves and Hashimoto’s have a common origin in the molecular mimicry theory
  • Grave's causes a hyperthyroid state, and Hashimoto's causes a hypothyroid state.

questions.text: Malignant hyperthermia is an autosomal dominant disorder where excess heat production occurs due to increased muscle metabolism by an excess of calcium ions. Which of the following gene defect is present in malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
• Malignant hyperthermia is an autosomal-dominant disease (affecting between 1 in 10,000 to1 in 50,000 individuals) in which the defect is in RyR1 gene.
  • The major features of the syndrome—hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and an increased metabolic rate.
  • When such individuals are administered inhalation anaesthetics (halothane or ether) or muscle relaxant succinylcholine, there is the excess release of Ca++in the sarcoplasm, increasing the muscle metabolism.
  • Treatment:Therapy for MH involves the administration of Dantrolene (MOA: blocks coupling between T tubules and SR, interrupting uncontrolled progression of muscle contractions), cessation of anesthesia, and aggressive efforts aimed at cooling the body.

During male development, the SRY gene turns on SOX9, which then turns on and forms a feedback loop with FGF9. The proliferation and differentiation of Sertoli cells are mainly activated by FGF9.

Barttin gene (also known as BSND) codes for the protein barttin; this protein recruits the Cl- channel CLCNKB to the basolateral membrane in the TAL of loop of Henle.

427-kDa gene: Dystrophin gene. Defects in this leads to Duchenne’s muscular dystrophy

questions.text: A child 5 years old was presented to a pediatrician by his parents with the history of frequent attacks of convulsions and unconsciousness. They also complained about his poor intake of food, weight loss, poor learning ability, fatigue and burnt sugar odour from urine. Plasma concentration of leucine is higher than 1000 micromol/L. What is the correct statement?

choices.text: Deficiency of branched chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex

questions.solution:
Burnt sugar like odor is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency ofbranched Chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase resulting in defect inoxidative decarboxylation and catabolism of branched chain amino acid -Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine.

Diagnosis

  1. Ferric chloride test: Detects Phenylpyruvate and Branched chain amino acid in urine.
  2. DNPH test – (Dinitro Phenyl Hydrazine): Detects α –Keto acids in urine.
  3. Confirmatory test: Detection of BCAA or BCKA in urine/blood by HPLC.

Clinical Features of MSUD

  • Burnt sugar like odor (because of increased isoleucine)
  • Ketosis (due to increases BCKA)
  • Mental retardation (because of increased leucine)
  • If not treated then coma (because of increased leucine)
  • Death can occur (high mortality rate)
  • Vomiting, feeding problems
  • Abnormal muscle tone

Treatment

  • Diet is given which is restricted in branched chain amino acids, but some amount given to allow normal growth.
  • Supplementation of Vit B1 can be helpful in some patients.

questions.text: Myelin sheath loss can occur because of direct damage to the myelin sheath or indirectly through a primarily genetic disorder or attack during inflammation or toxic exposure. Select the correct statement regarding myelin sheath.

choices.text: Formed by Oligodendrocytes in peripheral nerves
Formed by Schwann cells in the CNS

questions.solution:
• Myelin sheath in the CNS is formed by the oligodendrocytes.
  • Myelin sheath of the peripheral nerves is formed by the Schwann cells.
  • Oneoligodendrocyte helps myelination of approx. 30 neurons but myelinate multiple axons.
  • One Schwann cell helps myelination of 1 neuron.
  • In CNS - Unmyelinated axons are bare.
  • In PNS - Unmyelinated axons are not bare. They are surrounded by Schwann cell processes.
    • They do not form a multilayer covering but extend their processes, which surrounds the part of axons.
    • Schwann cell with its unmyelinated axons -Remak bundle.

questions.text: Amount of air a person can breathe in, beginning at normal expiratory level & distending the lungs to maximum amount is known as.:-
questions.solution:
Functional residual capacity:

  • It equals the EXPIRATORY RESERVE VOLUME + RESIDUAL VOLUME
  • This capacity is amount of air that remains in lungs at end of normal expiration (about 2300 ML)

Pulmonary capacities: Inspiratory capacity:

  • Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume [about 3500ml]
  • This capacity is amount of air a person can breathe in, beginning at normal expiratory level & distending the lungs to maximum amount.

Vital capacity:

  • Inspiratory reserve volume + tidal volume + expiratory reserve volume.
  • This capacity is max amount of air a person can expel from lungs after first filling the lungs to their maximum extent & then expiring to maximum extent (about 4600ml)

Total lung capacity:

  • Max vol to which lungs can be expanded with greatest possible effort [5800 ml]
  • Vital capacity + residual volume

questions.text: "Demographic burden" connotes the period when the dependency ratio in a population increase because of?
questions.solution:
• Dependency ratio= (Proportion of ppl in < 15yrs of age + >65yrs of age) / Proportion of ppl in 15-64 yrs. of age
  • If working age population will decrease dependency ratio will increase.
  • "Demographic burden" is used to connote the increase in the total dependency ratio during any period, mostly caused by increased old age dependency ratio
  • "Demographic bonus" connotes the period when the dependency ratio in a population declines because of decline in fertility, until it starts to rise again because of increasing longevity.

questions.text: Which of the following epidemiological study designs is best to determine association between risk factor and disease?

Cohort study gives the strongest evidence of association.

Cohort study is best to find out the incidence and compare it with exposed and not exposed.

Strength of association in cohort study is calculated by:

  • Relative risk - best indicator as it has lower biases as compared to other studies.
  • Attributable risk.
  • Population attributable risk.

questions.text: The incidence of carcinoma cervix in women with multiple sexual partners is 5 times the incidence seen in those with a single partner. Based on this, what is the attributable risk?
questions.solution:
• If the incidence of carcinoma cervix in those with single partner is 'x', then the incidence in those with multiple sexual partners will be 5 'x'.
  • Attributable risk = (Incidence in exposed – Incidence in non-exposed / Incidence in exposed) X 100 = (5x–x / 5x) X 100 = (4/5) X 100 = 80%.

questions.text: Select the correct statement regarding double-blind clinical drug trial -

Patient is blinded but investigator knows about the drugs given

questions.solution:
DOUBLE BLINDING:

  • In a double-blind trial, the patients as well as the investigator are blinded i.e., they don’t know who is receiving the study drug and who is receiving placebo.
  • It removes subject & investigator bias.
  • MC binding seen.

OTHER TYPES OF BLINDING: Single blinding:

  • Subjects are not aware of treatment. Used to remove subject bias.
  • Triple binding: Subject, investigator & analyser are not aware of treatment. Removes subject, investigator & analyser bias. It is best blinding.

questions.text: In which of the following autopsy techniques all the organs (Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs) are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
questions.solution:
In Letulle’s method thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block

Autopsy Techniques Advantage Disadvantage
Letulle’s Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed"en masse," as one big organ block. The best technique to see relations amongst organs.Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other Difficult to handle large mass.
Ghon’s Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks(en block) This method can also be used in Infants
Virchow’s Organs are removedone by one Most commonly used technique (easier to perform) Relations of organs are not preserved
Rokitansky In situdissection (inside the body itself) Good for infected bodies (prevents spreading of infection)

The below image shows Letulle’s technique where all the organs (Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic) have been removed "en masse," as one big organ block.

questions.text: Autopsy findings of the wound on the forehead of the gunshot victim was documented as a cruciate wound, with inverted edges, presence of singing of hairs and tattooing around the edges. What is the component of the fired shot which is responsible for the findings of tattooing?
questions.solution:
Effects of different discharges from a gun:

  • Bullet / Pellet → Gunshot wound (Puncture wound with abrasion collar)
  • Felt wad → Minor abrasion and bruise. burning at entrance wound along with burning or singeing of hairs. due to Fire / Flame

Singeing of hair/Scorching

  • due to the escape of hot gases by the sides of the muzzle end results in Singeing of hairs.

Lead/Metal ring

  • around entry wound Deposition of lead or other metal on the skin.

Dirt ring/projectile wipe ring

  • due to wiping of substances from surface of bullet as it passes through the skin like grease, barrel debris, soil particles, etc.
  • It is appreciable inner to the substance of the abraded/abraded-contused ring.

Abraded collar/abraded contused ring

  • Due to impact of the bullet coupled with abrading of the skin through its gyrating movements against skin

Soot or smoke soiling/blackening/smudging

  • Deposition of smoke over the epidermis.
  • These particles being light, do not travel afar (for virtually all hand gun cartridges, soot is absent around the entry wound where the muzzle-to-target distance is beyond one foot)

Tattooing/peppering/stippling

  • Due to embedding of semi-burnt and/or unburnt powder particles in the dermis (patterns of tattooing are usually not to be seen around the entry wound where the muzzle-to-target distance is over four feet)

questions.text: Which of the following protease inhibitors has an active metabolite and its bio-availability is not substantially improved with the addition of ritonavir?

Nelfinavir has an active metabolite, the only known active metabolite of any HIV protease inhibitor.

Nelfinavir

  • Undergoes oxidative metabolism primarily by CYP2C19 but also by CYP3A4 and CYP2D6.
  • Its major hydroxy-t-butylamide metabolite, M8, is formed by CYP2C19 and has in vitro.
  • Antiretroviral activity is similar to that of the parent drug.
  • This is the only known active metabolite of any HIV protease inhibitor.
  • Nelfinavir induces its own metabolism.

Nelfinaviris mainlymetabolizedviaCYP2C19.Ritonavir is a weak inhibitor of CYP2C19andwill not significantlyimprove the bioavailabilityof nelfinavir.

All other protease inhibitors are mainly metabolized by the CYP3A4 enzyme in the liver. Ritonavir is a potentCYP3A4 inhibitor and a potentCYP3A4 inhibitor.A drug boosterused in combination with other protease inhibitors.

  • On LPCB stain you observe sporangium, sporangiophore and rhizoids
  • Rhizoids absent- mucor
  • Rhizoids opposite to sporangiophore-Rhizopus
  • Rhizoids on side- absedia

questions.text: Orthotoluidine Arsenite test determines the free and combined chlorine residuals separately. In Orthotoluidine Arsenite test errors caused by the presence of interfering substances are overcome for all except?
questions.solution:
ORTHOTOLIDINE-ARSENITE (OTA)

  • Modification of the OT test to determine the free and combined chlorine residuals separately.
  • Errors caused by the presence of interfering substances such as nitrites,iron and manganese will produce a yellow colour with Orthotolidine, are overcome by the OTA test.
  • The test is carried out by adding 0.1 ml of the reagent to 1 ml of water.
  • The yellow colour produced is matched against suitable standards or colour discs.
  • It is essential to take the reading within 10 seconds after the addition of the reagent to estimate free chlorine in water.
  • The colour that is produced after a lapse, say 15-20 minutes, is due to the action of both free and combined chlorine.

questions.text: A 30yrs old patient was hit by a bull and later presented with complaint of abdominal pain for last 3 days and obstipation for last 2 days along with nausea and vomiting. So the most likely cause is hollow viscus perforation.

questions.text: You're an intern in Emergency room a 25 year old male patient who is on treatment for fracture neck of talus came for follow up. Your attending orthopaedic surgeon ordered for an ankle x ray. Your senior postgraduate points out the presence of subchondral lucent line in the xray and asks you what does it signify ?
questions.solution:
The Presence of subchondral lucency is indicative of intact blood supply to the talus.

This sign is known as Hawkins sign and is usually seen after 6 weeks of the fracture.

Presence of this sign excludes the complication of avascular necrosis of the body of the talus.

Complications of fracture of talus are:

  • Osteoarthritis of the subtalar joint (most common complication)
  • Avascular necrosis of body of talus
  • Malunion

questions.text: A 40-year-old female who was a case of seizure disorder posted for total thyroidectomy under general anaesthesia. She had shivering in the perioperative period which was treated with Inj. Pethidine 25 mg IM. This postoperative shivering should be treated promptly because it is associated with-

choices.text: Decreased heart rate and blood pressure

questions.solution:
Postoperative shivering

  • Postoperative shivering is usually but not always associated with hypothermia. Its incidence may be as high as 66% in general anaesthesia. Although thermoregulatory mechanisms explain shivering in hypothermic patients, different mechanisms have been proposed to explain shivering in normothermic patients. Brain and spinal cord do not recover simultaneously from general anaesthesia. More rapid recovery of spinal cord function results in uninhibited spinal reflexes manifests as clonic activity.
  • Risk factors -young age, endoprosthetic surgery, core hypothermia
  • Postoperative shivering can greatly increase oxygen consumption, catecholamine release, cardiac output, heart rate and blood pressure, and intracerebral and intraocular pressure.
  • Many drugs, notably meperidine, clonidine, and tramadol, clonidine, ketamine, ondansetron can be used to reduce postoperative shivering once it starts. Of those meperidine 12.5-25 mg iv most used in adults. prevention of hypothermia and intraoperative dexmedetomidine infusion are prophylactic measures.

questions.text: A man who suffered an attack of stroke was brought to emergency he had a history of urine turning black. On thorough testing it was concluded that patient has a low NAP score and CD55 deficiency. What drug therapy will be given in such patient?
questions.solution:
PAROXYSMAL NOCTURNAL HEMOGLOBINURIA (PNH)

  • CD 55 deficiency.
  • RBC vulnerable to complement mediated destruction.
  • Results in Urine turning black.
  • Low Neutrophil alkaline phosphatase (NAP) score.
  • There is ↑ Thrombogenic potential due to ↑ TXA2 production - leads to Platelet aggregation.
  • Leads to Budd -Chiari syndrome, Stroke
  • IOC - Flow cytometry
  • DOC - Eculizumab
  • Ideal Treatment - Bone Marrow Transplant

questions.text:
12 y/o child was brought with chief complaints of bone pain in lower end of femur mainly during night-time which is relieved by taking aspirin. x ray findings of the condition are as given below.

What is the treatment of choice for this condition?

choices.text: NSAIDS and radio frequency ablation or excision

questions.solution:
Osteoid Osteoma

  • Night pain relieved by taking salicylates
  • Cortical tumour “Thickened Cortex”
  • Diaphysis
  • Nidus → Lytic centre with Sclerotic margin
  • Nidus (seed) has
  1. Osteoblast
  2. Osteoclast
  • Periphery is dark & centre is light

Rx: Radio frequency oblation > surgical excision

questions.text: A patient presented with vesicular lesions over single dermatome over chest, he also complains of pain what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above given clinical scenario is suggestive of shingles which is caused by Herpes Zoster virus
  • Generally lesions of shingles are present along a particular nerve segment (particular dermatome) and are grouped, painfull and vesicular lesions
  • They are generally unilateral.

questions.text: A patient came to the ER with complaint of muscle cramps and weakness. On blood examination hypokalaemia was noted. Which of the following ECG findings will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Prolonged QT interval with flat T-waves
Decreased QT interval with tall T-waves
Decreased PR interval with ST depression
Prolonged PR interval with ST elevation

questions.solution:
Prolonged QT interval with flat T-waves is seen in hypokalaemia.

Hypokalaemia prolongs the ventricular repolarisation. The ECG changes seen are as follows:

  • Flattening of T wave
  • ST-segment depression
  • Prolongation of QT interval
  • The appearance of U wave

questions.text: Surgical resection is carried out in 68-year woman with uterine cancer. This cancer can spread directly to labia majora in lymphatics that follow which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
• Round ligament of uterus runs laterally from the uterus through deep inguinal ring, inguinal canal, and superficial inguinal ring and becomes lost in the subcutaneous tissues of the labium majus.

Thus, carcinoma of the uterus can spread directly to the labium majus by traveling in lymphatics that follow the ligament.

  • The pubic arcuate ligament attaches across the inferior aspect of pubic symphysis and attaches to medial borders of the inferior pubic rami.
  • The suspensory ligament of the ovary runs from ovary to pelvic wall and transmits the ovarian vessels.
  • The cardinal (transverse cervical) ligament runs from the cervix and the vagina to pelvic walls.
  • The suspensory ligament of clitoris runs from pubic symphysis and arcuate pubic ligament to deep fascia of the body of the clitoris.

questions.text: An 8 years old child is presented with short stature, obesity, bowing of legs and trident hands. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant condition.

D – Delayed motor milestones
R – Recognized at birth
O – Bowing of legs
P – Proximal limb shortening
L – Large head
S – Short stature
I – Interpedicular distance between vertebrae is decreased

  • Rickets- Wrist widening (splaying), fraying & cupping
  • Scurvy- pencil-thin outline of the cortex, Wimberger sign, subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Osteopetrosis- bone appears white/ Marble bone disease

questions.text: Ebb and flow are two phases of metabolic response to injury. Pick the odd statement.

choices.text: Ebb phase lasts for 10days and is known as energy consuming phase.
In flow phase insulin thyroid hormone and growth hormones increases.
In catabolic part of flow phase there is negative nitrogen balance
In ebb phase BMR, thyroid hormone, body temperature, all decreases.

questions.solution:
ebb and flow phase

PHASE ROLE PHYSIOLOGY
EBB(<24hours) Maintain blood volume and catecholamines. Decreased BMR and O2 consumption, low thyroid and low insulin
Flow
1. Catabolic phase(3-10days Maintain energy Increase BMR and O2 consumption. Negative nitrogen balance
2. Anabolic phase Replacement of damaged tissue Growth hormones and insulin increase. Positive nitrogen balance.

questions.text: A young female, with a 28-day regular cycle, is your patient. If she comes to your clinic today and mentions that it is the first day of her usually ‘5-days’ long menses, and insists that she is interested in bearing a child, you mention a window to her to maximise chances of getting pregnant. This revolves around the fact that the sperm, on average, remains fertile in the female genital tract for:
questions.solution:
• Spermatozoa remain fertile for 48 hrs after ejaculation but can survive for 5-10 days in the female reproductive tract.
  • Only 1% of sperm deposited in the vagina enter the cervix.
  • Movements of sperm from the cervix to the Fallopian tube occur by muscular contractions of the uterus & the Fallopian tube. (very little role of their own propulsion).

questions.text: Which of the following are components of the definitive chorion?

choices.text: Extraembryonic somatic mesoderm, cytotrophoblast, and syncytiotrophoblast

questions.solution:
• The definitive chorion consists of three components:extra embryonic somatic mesoderm, cytotrophoblast, and syncytiotrophoblast.
  • The chorion defines the chorionic cavity in which the embryoblast is suspended and is vital in the formation of the placenta.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents at 10 weeks of pregnancy. She is a known case of epilepsy on anticonvulsant therapy. Which of the following is true about pharmacotherapy of this patient in pregnancy?

choices.text: Sodium valproate is the drug of choice.
Therapeutic drug monitoring is not required
Folic acid supplementation prevents risk of NTD in these patients
Lamotrigine is the most teratogenic drug.

questions.solution:
• Sodium valproate is the most teratogenic drug.
  • Lamotrigine is the DOC.
  • All anticonvulsant drugs are associated with congenital anomalies. Therapeutic drug monitoring is required.
  • Vitamin K 10 mg/day orally from 36 weeks should be given to the mother.

EPILEPSY IN PREGNANCY

Pregnancy-related risks

  • increased seizure rates: upto 20-30%. This has two important causes:
    • lower seizure threshold
    • subtherapeutic anticonvulsant levels
  • fetal malformations: more likely due to anticonvulsant than epilepsy itself

Pregnancy complications

  • spontaneous abortions
  • APH and PPH
  • hypertensive disorders
  • preterm birth
  • IUGR c
  • esarean delivery

Anticonvulsant therapy

  • lowest dose monotherapy is the goal. Multidrug therapy increases risk of malformations
  • preferable to increase dose if needed than add another drug
  • phenytoin, phenobarbital, valproate: known teratogens with known fetal malformation risk
  • lamotrigine and levetiracetam: lowest risk of malformation
  • most are safe with breast feeding

questions.text: 6 years old undernourished female child was brought to emergency department with generalized tonic-clonic seizure associated with fever. Neuroimaging reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions with perifocal edema. Blood examination reveals an eosinophilic picture. Which of the following is the drug is used for management in this child?
questions.solution:
Seizures associated with ring-enhancing lesions and eosinophilic picture points towards diagnosis of Neurocysticercosis.

Neurocysticercosis - Parasitic infestation of the brain by encysted larvae of pork tapeworm T. solium.

Albendazole is the anti-helminthic of choice for the treatment of neurocysticercosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, married for 3 years is unable to conceive. She is otherwise healthy but has delayed menstrual cycles. Which of the following drug should be used first-line in her next cycle for her condition?

Letrozole is the Drug of choice- Induction of ovulation in a case of PCOS;

    • Aromatase Inhibitor

  • Letrozole preferred over Clomiphene citrate because
    • decreases chances of multifetal pregnancy
    • increased live birth rate
    • OHSS : Rare with it
  • Given for 5 days (D5-D9)
    • Start with 2.5mg
    • Max dose 7.5mg

questions.text:
Which of the following findings in patients of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) can mimic as a case of acute pancreatitis?
1. Elevated amylase
2. Elevated lipase
3. Abdominal pain
4. Hyperglycaemia
questions.solution:
Elevated serum lipase is not associated with DKA. It is specific to acute pancreatitis.

  • DKA has a similar presentation like acute pancreatitis with abdominal pain, hyperglycaemia, and elevated serum amylase.Serum lipase can differentiate both.

Differential diagnosis of acute pancreatitis

  • Biliary colic
  • Acute cholecystitis
  • Perforated hollow viscus (e.g., perforated peptic ulcer)
  • Mesenteric ischemia or infarction
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Dissecting aortic aneurysm
  • Ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A patient came in with complaint of watery diarrhoea that even persists on fasting. On examination we found that the patient also had achlorhydria and hypokalaemia. Which of the following can it be?
questions.solution:
VIPOMA

  • Excess production of vasoactive intestinal polypeptide
  • It is series of 28 AA.
  • Present in GIT / CNS
  • Functions as neurotransmitter – it causes opening of water channel in gut – causing secretory diarrhea
  • VIPoma is a tumor related to cells in pancreas [F cells – produce VIP]
  • Consisting of stool is just like stools in cholera. Therefore, also known as pancreatic cholera
  • Large volume depletion therefor, will cause hypokalemia, dehydration, achlorhydria
    • If severe → M acidosis

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect regarding congenital diaphragmatic hernia?

choices.text: Bochdalek hernia is on left posterolateral side
Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in congenital diaphragmatic hernia
Morgagni hernia is also known as retrosternal hernia
Dextrocardia is never seen these patients

questions.solution:
CDH – Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

Bochdalek Hernia

  • Most common type of CDH
  • Aka left sided posterolateral Hernia
  • Incidence -1 in 2000-5000 live births
  • Cause - Failure of fusion of pleuro peritoneal canal at left side
  • Bag and mask ventilation are contraindicated.
  • Because there is failure of fusion of pleuro peritoneal canal at let side, left sided structures like spleen, stomach and transverse colon herniate above causing ipsilateral collapse of lung and shifting of heart to right side (dextrocardia)
  • The lest-out space at the abdomen due to herniation, causes the scaphoid abdomen.

Morgagni Hernia

  • Aka Larrey's Hernia
  • Aka Right sided/ retrosternal Hernia
  • In between the right side of xiphoid process and central tendon of diaphragm, there is a shape known as space of Larrey
  • Superior epigastric vessels are passing via the space of Larrey
  • If there is defective development of central tendon of diaphragm, the space of Larrey / Morgagni is enlarged leading to high chances of herniation of transverse colon.
  • MC in right side
  • MC organ herniated - Transverse colon
  • Incidental finding

questions.text: Which of the following are bad prognostic factor in a patient with Schizophrenia?

choices.text: Early onset, female sex, catatonic type
Acute onset, catatonic type, male sex
History of mood disorder in the family

questions.solution:
Schizophrenia

Good Prognosis Bad Prognosis
Acute onset (<2 weeks) Insidious onset
Advanced age at onset (>35 year) Early onset <20 year)
Catatonic subtype (Paranoid subtype has an intermediate prognosis) Simple, disorganized, hebephrenic
Female Sex Male Sex
Prominent Positive Symptom Prominent Negative symptom, aggressive symptoms
Presence of affective symptom Absence of affective symptoms
Family H/O mood disorder Family h/o Schizophrenia
Good premorbid functioning and personality traits Poor premorbid functioning and personality traits

HOW TO REMEMBER:Well-begun is half done. If Premorbid personality is good, patient prognosis will be good.

questions.text: A newborn was presented with defect in abdominal wall as shown in picture. Pick the odd statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: It is related with congenital anomalies
Bowel is covered with peritoneal sac
Liver cannot herniate through this defect

questions.solution: Omphalocele – It is a birth defect of the abdominal (belly) wall. The infant's intestines, liver, or other organs come outside of the belly through the belly button. The organs are covered in a thin, nearly transparent sac that hardly ever is broken.

questions.text: A patient came to the ER with complaint of bloody urine and swelling in hands and feet. He also gave the history that he must get up at night a lot to urinate. On immunofluorescence - IgA, IgG, IgM, C1q, C3 all deposited in subepithelial and subendothelial was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The above given immunofluorescence report of - IgA, IgG, IgM, C1q, C3 all deposited in subepithelial and subendothelial is called Full House effect and this is commonly seen in lupus nephritis. Lupus nephritis is one of the important reasons of mortality in Active SLE infection.

questions.text: A rose gardener following prick injury develops the skin changes. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
• The rose gardener after prick injury develops nodular lesions present in linear arrangement over the extremity (as shown in image above), is suggestive of sporotrichosis.
  • It is a fungal infection caused by “Sporothrix schenckii”
  • It is also called rose gardeners disease
  • The common variant is lymphatic variant.
  • On the site of injury, a nodular lesion is formed from where the causative agent enters the lymphatics and forms multiple lesions along the lymphatic drainage.
  • The lesions are present in linear fashion.
  • Lesions are generally present over extremities

questions.text: A 19-year-old female, came to your clinic with a complaint of not having menses even once. You notice that she has normal secondary sexual development, and order for an ultrasound. It reveals that there is an absence of uterus and upper part of vagina, while lower 2/3rd of vagina is still present. You begin to consider MRKH syndrome and explain to patient that the lower part of vagina is present since it develops separate from the rest, from the:-
questions.solution:
• Lower 2/3rd of vagina formed from sinovaginal bulb which comes from endoderm of urogenital sinus.
  • Upper 1/3rd of vagina is derived from fused paramesonephric duct.
  • Mesonephric duct forms the collecting part or ductular part of male reproductive system.
  • Mesoderm of Müllerian duct is basically paramesonephric duct.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a selective shunt surgery for portal vain hypertension?
questions.solution:
Selective and non-selective shunts

Shunts:

Types of shunts

  1. Non selective
  2. Selective
  3. Partial

Non-selective shunts

  1. Eck fistula
  2. Side to side ports-caval shunt (SSPCS)
  3. Inter position graft
    1. Portocaval
    2. Mesocaval
    3. Mesorenal
  4. Proximal splenorenal shunt (PSRS)/Linton's shunt

Selective shunt

  1. DSRS (Warren shunt) — distal splenorenal shunt
  2. INOKUCHI shunt

questions.text: A 3 year old girl child was brought to anganwaadi and her mother complains that she doesn’t eat and is less active and her height is less than other children of her age. On examination her height is 84 cm. what should be the expected height of this child?
questions.solution:
To calculate expected height according to age of a child:
Expected height: 6x + 77 cm (where x is age in years).
So 6(3) + 77 = 95
Therefore expected height of child is 95cm

questions.text: The obstetrician is assessing the pelvis of a primigravida for assessing chances of a normal vaginal delivery. Which of the following is normally the smallest diameter of the true pelvis?
questions.solution:
• The midpelvis is measured at the level of the ischial spines, also called the midplane or plane of least pelvic dimensions.
  • The level of ischial spines serves to mark 'zero' station . The interspinous diameter is 10 cm or slightly greater, is usually the smallest pelvic diameter, and, in cases of obstructed labor, is particularly important.
  • The anteroposterior diameter of the midpelvis through the level of the ischial spines normally measures at least 11.5 cm.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with features of poor perfusion following MI. On examination, heart rate is 40/min with BP of 60 mmHg systolic. Atropine was given twice over 5 minutes, but the condition of the patient is not improving. What is the next best step?
questions.solution: ACLS 2015 guidelines: Case of symptomatic bradycardia with signs of poor perfusion-->Transcutaneous pacingis recommended.

questions.text: 25 years old female came to ENT OPD with complaints of B/L hearing loss and also complaints of better hearing whenever they play music in loudspeaker near her house. what will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Otosclerosis

  • also known as otospongiosis predominant in females (20-30 years) autosomal dominant pattern
  • B/L CHL Schwartz sign- flamingo pink colour of tympanic membrane pure tone audiometry-Carhart’s notch- dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction

PARACUSIS WILLISII:

  • Patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings.
  • This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings.
  • Can also be seen in patients with Bilateral conductive hearing loss

questions.text: A child was bought to the ER. On examination it was found that he had periorbital edema, urine was foamy and on further testing he was noted to have selective proteinuria. On HPE effaced foot process were seen. The treating physician started him on steroids but after 4 weeks still no recovery was seen. What will the physician start next?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of this child suggests nephrotic syndrome.

NEPHROTIC SYNDROME

Minimal Change Disease (MCD)

  • A child with Nephrotic syndrome - MCD
  • Periorbital edema
  • Foamy Urine
  • Aetiology - Idiopathic (mcc)> NSAIDS
  • Selective proteinuria seen (Low molecular weight proteins lost in urine)
  • Diurnal variation of oedema (Start from Eyes — genitals — feet)
  • HPE - Foot Process Effacement.

Diagnosis

  • Spot Urine - UAC
  • 24 hr. Urinary protein > 3.5 g

Treatment

  • MCD is steroid responsive nephrotic syndrome.
  • Steroid dependent Nephrotic Syndrome (SDNS) - Give Steroids.
  • SDNS with Toxicity (weight gain, hirsutism, proximal myopathy) - Cyclophosphamide.
  • Steroid Resistant Nephrotic Syndrome – Cyclosporine.

questions.text:
Which of the following modalities are used for the diagnosis of placenta accreta?
1.USG
2.MRI
3.Angiography
4.Radiography
questions.solution: In placenta accreta, the placenta in morbidly adherent to the uterine lining Initial investigation of choice is suspected cases of placenta accreta is USG The best investigation of choice is MRI Angiography and radiography have no role in the diagnosis of placenta accreta

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV positive individual presented with a 6 week history of 6 watery bowel movements per day. His routine stool examination results had been negative. The patient has reported a weight loss of 4 kg since the onset of diarrhoea. What do you think is the most common cause of diarrhoea in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cryptosporidia microsporidia and Isospora belli are the most common opportunistic protozoa that infect the GI tract and cause diarrhea in HIV-infected patients.

  • Diarrhea is accompanied by crampy abdominal pain, nausea and/or vomiting.
  • Diagnosis-stool examination or biopsy of the small intestine.
  • The diarrhea is noninflammatory and the characteristic finding is the presence of oocysts that stain with acid-fast dyes.
  • Therapy is predominantly supportive
  • Treatment: with up to2000 mg/d of nitazoxanide (NTZ)is associated with improvement in symptoms or a decrease in shedding of organisms in about half of patients.

questions.text: A woman presents at 25 weeks pregnancy with complains of white discharge per vaginum. On examination, the discharge is whitish, homogenous and associated with fishy odour.   • Microscopy:-Clue cells-
  • Vaginal epithelium with embedded bacteria
  • No pruritus,
  • The Whiff test- The addition of KOH to the vaginal secretions releases a amine like odor.
  • Amsel's criteria is used for diagnosis
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole,
    • Treat the woman(No sexual transmission)

  • Although no drug is considered absolutely safe in the first trimester , there is a relative safety of usage of class ‘B’ drugs in pregnancy. Metronidazole comes under that class where the drug is safe in animal studies and also in most human studies.
  • If given a choice in first trimester, its prudent to use an absolute safe agent like betadine vaginal pessary which will buy time till the patient is in the second trimester for safe usage of category B or even C category drugs.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is complaining of a bearing-down sensation in her womb and an increased frequency of and burning sensation on urination. On examination by her gynecologist, she is diagnosed with a uterine prolapse. Which of the following structures provides the most significant support for the cervix of the uterus?
questions.solution:
Solutions:

  • The cardinal (transverse cervical) ligament provides the major ligamentous support for the uterus.
  • The sphincter ani externus does not support the uterus.
  • The broad and round ligaments of the uterus provide minor supports for the uterus.
  • The suspensory ligament of the ovary does not support the uterus.

Supports of Uterus

    • Muscular (dynamic supports) - provide excellent support
      • Pelvic diaphragm (levator ani and coccygeus)
      • Urogenital diaphragm (urethral sphincter and deep transverse perinei)
      • Perinea! body (common perinea) tendon for the attachment of numerous perinea! muscles)
    • Pelvic fascia condensations (passive supports) ??" provide good support
      • Transverse cervical ligaments (of Mackenrodt)
      • Pubocervical ligaments
      • Uterosacral (sacrocervical) ligaments
    • Peritoneal folds - provide poor support
      • Broad ligaments
      • Round ligament of uterus (remnant of the gubernaculum in the embryo)
      • Uterovesical fold of peritoneum
      • Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum
    • Uterine position and axis (anteflexed and anteverted)

questions.text: A 70-year-old female came to OPD with complaint of recurrent Herpes labialis and enlarged lymph nodes. On examination hepatosplenomegaly and non-blanching petechiae around then knee was seen. The image given below was seen on peripheral smear. On what medication will you start the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture points towards CLL (chronic lymphoid leukaemia)

CLL

Clinical features

Median age of presentation: 72 years

Females > males

1. Progressive cervical lymphadenopathy, night sweats

2. Infections: Recurrent Pneumonia, Herpes labialis, herpes zoster

3. Antibodies against self

  • Platelets
    • Non blanching petechiae near the ankles
  • RBCs →AIHA
    • Progressive pallor + purpura Epistaxis

4. Hepatosplenomegaly (infiltration of cancer cell in liver & spleen)

Work up:

1. TLC ­ (4K – 11K) – B cell lymphocytosis > 5000 / mL x 3 months

2. On peripheral smear – SMUDGE cells which are fragile, immune incompetent B cell which breaks down by pressure of glass slide.

3. IOC → flow cytometry CLL → CD19, CD20 (dim), CD21, CD23, CD5

  • B cell presents with T cell marker.

Treatment

  • Low risk, stage A: 75-year-old – conservative management
  • High risk: fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, Rituximab (FCR) or pentostatin, Cyclophosphamide, Rituximab (PCR)

TOC: Allogenic Bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother as she has started to have cyclical vaginal bleeding since 3 months. She also has started showing signs of breast development and growth of pubic and axillary hair. On laboratory testing her LH and FSH are found to be in the range similar to reproductive age women. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy in this case?
questions.solution:
This girl has presented with onset of menarche along with other signs of puberty such as breast development, pubic and axillary hair growth. These along with raised LH and FSH are suggestive of central precocious puberty.

Most effective treatment for central precocious puberty is the use of a Long-acting GnRH agonist, such as leuprolide and others.

  • These drugs act by down regulating pituitary gonadotropes, eventually decreasing the secretion of FSH and LH, which are inappropriately stimulating the ovaries.
  • As a result of this induced hypogonadotropic state, ovarian hormones (oestrogens, progestins, and androgens) are suppressed back to pre-pubertal levels, and precocious pubertal development stops or regresses.
  • During the first 1 or 2 weeks of therapy, there is a flare-up effect of increased gonadotropins and sex steroids-a predicted side effect of these medications.
  • At the time of expected puberty, the GnRH analogue is discontinued and the pubertal sequence resumes.

  • Children equal to or >1 year of age or weighing >8 kg: 2 lakh IU orally on days 0,1 and 14
  • IM dose is half of the oral dose

questions.text: Leber cells are most commonly seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Leber cells are mainly seen in trachoma

Follicles:

  • Conjunctival follicles multiple discrete resembling grains of rice, blood vessels run across or around.
  • Subepithelial lymphoid germinal centers with histiocytes, monocytes and large nucleated cells called Leber cells with immature lymphocytes centrally and mature cells peripherally.
  • Leber cells and necrosis is mainly seen in trachoma.
  • Causes: Viral & chlamydial conjunctivitis

PseudoMembrane

  • Adenoviral
  • Gonococcal
  • Ligneous
  • Steven jhonson

Papilla

  • IN PALPEBRAL CONJUNCTIVA & Limbal bulbar conjunctiva
  • Vascular core is present
  • Hyperplastic conjunctival epithelium with vascular core
  • Bacterial conjunctivitis, allergic conjunctivitis, marginal conjunctivitis, contact lens wear

questions.text:
Which of the following tests can be used in the diagnosis of galactosemia?

GALT assay
Homogentisic acid oxidase assay
Benedict’s test
Guthrie’s test
questions.solution:
• Deficiency of:
    • GALT (Galactose 1 PO4 uridyl transferase): Most common
    • Galactokinase
  • Autosomal recessive
  • Clinical features: Jaundice, hepatomegaly, seizures, cataract, diarrhea, vomiting, failure to thrive
  • Breast feeding also contraindicated
  • Diagnosis:
    • Benedict's test positive: Presence of reducing substance in urine
    • Direct enzyme assay (GALT assay)
    • Mutation analysis
    • Treatment: Lactose free diet

GUTHRIE TEST: used for phenylketonuria

HOMOGENTISIC ACID OXIDASE assay: used for Alkaptonuria

questions.text: 28 years old male came to the emergency department with an alleged history of a road traffic accident and sustained injury over the face. CT- scan revealed maxilla bone fracture. Which of the following is the most common nerve to be injured?
questions.solution:
Clinical Features of maxillary fractures:

  • Ecchymosis of lid, conjunctiva and sclera
  • Enophthalmos with inferior displacement of the eyeball or entrapment of inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscles.
  • Hypoesthesia or anaesthesia of cheek and upper lip, if infraorbital nerve is involved

PRINCIPLES OF MANAGEMENT EMERGENCY TREATMENT

  • Midfacial fractures can easily compromise the airway with torrential epistaxis and posterior impaction of the maxilla. The bleeding can be arrested by using epistaxis or anterior and posterior nasal packs.

REDUCTION

  • The maxilla is mobilized by a combination of digital pressure and traction on arch bars or interdental wires.

FIXATION

  • Internal fixation with the mini plates.

questions.text: A patient came to the Cardiology department with complaint of tightness in chest on initial pulse examination physician described patients pulse as ‘Pulsus Parvus et Tardus’. What will be the initial diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Anacrotic Pulse

  • Slow rise of pulse with a small or absent Dicrotic Notch.
  • Seen in Valvular Aortic Stenosis (AS).
  • Also known as Pulsus Parvus et Tardus

questions.text: A 5 month old baby was brought to the hospital with bilateral undescended testis. What is the most appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Wait and watch for spontaneous resolution
GnRH for one month then surgical treatment

questions.solution:
• Maternal chorionic gonadotropin stimulates the growth of the testis and migration of testis.
  • The patients who have undescended testis , spontaneous descent occurs till 3 months of age.
  • If spontaneous descent does not occur we have to perform orchidopexy, best age for orchidopexy is 6 months and should not be delayed beyond 12 months.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to a local hospital for surgery for uterine cancer. As the uterine artery passes from the internal iliac artery to the uterus, which of the following structures crossing inferior to it is sometimes mistakenly ligated during such surgery?
questions.solution:
• The ureter runs under the uterine artery near the cervix; thus, the ureter is sometimes mistakenly ligated during pelvic surgery.
  • The other structures mentioned are not closely related to the uterine artery near the uterine cervix.

questions.text: A 54 year old multiparous female presents with leakage of urine while coughing or laughing. This is called as:
questions.solution:
Stress incontinence is involuntary leakage of urine when there is increased intra-abdominal pressure that is while coughing or sneezing. It is more common in females who had normal vaginal delivery.

Urge incontinence is urgency followed by involuntary leakage of urine.

questions.text: Placenta is a temporary organ formed during pregnancy and is essential for the foetus to receive required oxygen and also to remove waste products from foetal circulation. Placenta develops from-
questions.solution:
Development of placenta:

  • Placenta has two components : Maternal & Fetal
  • When the blastocyst attaches to uterus in endometrium, the endometrium is called as decidua which is of three types:
  • Decidua basalis, Decidua capsularis & Decidua parietalis.
  • Fetus will also have some chorionic membrane developing leading tovilliformation :Chorion Frondosum & Chorionlaeve.
  • Chorion laeve will disappear.
  • Chorionic Frondosum persists & contributes to placenta along with Decidua Basalis .

questions.text: All are features of Sensorineural hearing loss Except
questions.solution:
CHARACTERISTICS OF SNHL

  • A positive Rinne test, i.e. AC > BC.
  • Weber lateralized to better ear.
  • Bone conduction reduced on Schwalbach and absolute bone conduction tests.
  • More often involving high frequencies.
  • No gap between air and bone conduction curve on audiometry (Figure 5.6).
  • Loss may exceed 60 dB.
  • Speech discrimination is poor. There is difficulty in hearing in the presence of noise.
